SENT.plain: We describe a patient without a previous history of migraine or epilepsy and with no known vascular risk factors, who suffered subarachnoid haemorrhage
During vertebral angiography using nonionic contrast medium (iohexol), spasm of the basilar artery was seen
The patient suffered transient global amnesia
Angiography 3 months later with the same contrast medium was normal and produced no further deficit
This case lends support to the supposed ischaemic aetiology of transient global amnesia; in patients without other evidence of cerebrovascular disease, arterial spasm may be responsible
